title: What is the average salary of a wedding photographer? - Quora

response.answer_text: So much goes into the coverage for your wedding day. Each wedding is unique in size and scope and each geographic area requires a different amount of expenses for that photographer. A town hall elopement, with just your parents and siblings, will be priced differently than a three day affair with 500 guests at an island destination. Legitimate professional photographers have one of the highest overheads: constant maintenance and cleaning of camera, lens and lighting equipment, which needs to be updated every 3 years or so. Computers with high speed processors, tons of RAM, many 4 TB external hard drives to back up the images in multiple places, at least 50 flash cards. Then there are the monthly subscription services for: Photoshop, Bridge, InDesign, Email marketing, Freshbooks, Quickbooks, web server, listing fees on Style Me Pretty ($100/month), The Knot ($250/month), Wedding Wire, etc…yes all of the places where you find your photographers charge a hefty listing fee. Then we have to insure all of our equipment and the venues, churches and synagogues that we work at all require us to to have liability insurance of up to $1 million, $2 million in NYC, in our riders. If we are listed on a venue’s referral list we are required to pay that venue 10% of our contracted fee. So you can see, just the business side of it to get out the door is very expensive. And, at least 25% of whatever we make goes to Federal and State taxes. A great second shooter runs typically $60-$100 hour for the day and a lighting assistant $50/hour. Most weddings in NYC have about 200 guests and 4 locations. So, the expense is much larger for this type of situation (rather than a suburban wedding), as we will need to have a photographer stationed at each location, because we don’t know what type of delays will occur at one location, while the bride and groom, may arrive to the 2nd, 3rd or 4th location before the original photographer does. Also, myself and my photographers all work with backup equipment. Once I had 6 pieces of equipment fail at one wedding! No matter though, I arrive to every wedding with duplicate equipment. It’s a wedding and you CAN’T miss a moment! Experience also plays a huge factor. I know that I won’t miss a moment (unless a guest jumps in front of me with their iPhone), because I know where to place myself to find those moments and capture them with crisp lighting. If it rains, if the ceremony is lit with one candle and running one hour behind, if the groomsmen are drunk, if there are a huge variety of characters within the family, I can navigate the situation. My study of the human form enables me to pose my subjects in the most flattering way and I can give direction to my couples to elicit their natural magic so that they are not posing, but showing their true selves in the photos. A great wedding photographer will have a keen understanding of the dynamics and subtleties of the wedding day and will have prepared for the day for the full year by meeting with the couple to get to know their personalities, understanding the vision and aesthetic cues of the wedding and ensuring that the images reflect them as a couple, and all of the relationships and connections present, this takes time and cultivation. A typical NYC wedding with 10 hours and 200 guests can run anywhere from $4,000-$20,000 depending upon the experience of the photographer. It’s kind of like a car, you can get a Toyota, or a Ferrari, you get what you pay for. Most wedding photographers love their job. I certainly do, my goal for all of my couples is that their children look back on their grandparent’s wedding day and feel all of the love that they were born in to. It’s a huge responsibility.

It all depends on their packages and what you are look for. Since photographers and videographers work together quite closely, you probably want to hire these professionals at about the same time. And because the photographer you choose is going to capture your day minute by minute, you will want to feel comfortable with this person. You may ask your photographer, (whom you should hire first) for a referral. Here are the questions to ask before you do anything. Questions for the Photographer 1. What’s the photographer’s primary style - traditional posed shots and portraits or photojournalism? (Ask to see their work to know the real answer to this question) 2. What’s his or her philosophy about shooting weddings? (This will give you an idea of the person’s expertise and passion for his or her work, too.) 3. Does the photographer shoot in color, black & white or both? 4. Will the photographer you talk to be the one taking the pictures at your wedding? (This is crucial! Each photographer’s style is his or her own. This question applies to the videographer, also) 5. Is his or her open to a list of must-have photos (the people whom you definitely want shots of.) 6. Does the photographer develop his or her own film? How long does he or she keep the negatives? Can you buy your negatives from the photographer 7. Has the photographer done many weddings? (A photographer who doesn't specialize in weddings is a risk. You want someone who is experienced with how a wedding works so that key moments are not missed!) Questions for the Videographer What’s the videographer’s style- artsy, documentary, or direct (doing interviews with guests)? Does this vibe with what you want. 2. Has the videographer done many weddings; how many? What’s his or her approach when it comes to taping a wedding? (This clues you into experience and philosophy. You want someone who’s experienced with how a wedding works so that key moments are not missed.) 3. How many other weddings is the videographer doing on your wedding day or weekend? (Make sure there are no time constraints. This question applies to the photographer, too) 4. How obtrusive are the shooting style and the crew? How bright are the lights they use? (If shooting requires the room lights to be on all evening, much of the romance will be lost) 5. What kind, how many, and how new are the cameras, tapes, and microphones the videographer uses? (Can you get a DVD instead of a video?) 6. Has the videographer worked with your photographer before? How does he or she coordinate with a wedding photographer? (This is really important) Remember, always ask about pricing and packages; get a current price list to help you make a decision.

I know it is not what you want to hear, as it is not what I wanted to hear when I first started as a photographer. But photography like many other craft/jobs in the arts is not something you can stick a salary to. First there are a ton of different factors that add up not only to your bottom line but also how much you should charge your clients.  First, it depends where you live. Simple supply and demand will not only dictate your competition but also your rates. As such, it does not matter how good you are, if you are in a market that cannot afford your prices then you will starve, unless you lower your prices and thus make less money. Also, that is not a necessarily a bad thing since your money can travel further in a small city than it would in say, New York.  Second, how much can you provide your clients in terms of quality? There are both an educated and a hardware value. Yes, being creative and having a great eye is a salable asset but the hardware you bring to a job also will dictate how much you should/can charge per weddings/jobs. My photographer friend who shoots mostly weddings, easily walks into a job with $15,000 worth of equipment (2 full frames, with 24-70mm and 70-200mm, plus other lenses and primes, multiple flash guns, backgrounds, even a small electric generator to power his own light sets in case it rains, etc)  ...Anyway, compare my friend to a small-fry wedding photographer and he will beat him under the table in terms of flexibility and reliable quality. Period.  As such, he could ask for $3000+ a wedding while the other guy could only ask $1000 at best depending on expectations. However, with a higher paycheck also comes a higher bottom line, after all, my friend has to pay for all that hardware, plus insurance, plus hardware upgrades, plus earn enough to eat and pay for extra staff if he needs to.  As Laurence mentioned, some photographers may work for a larger studio but generally they get paid less than if they worked on their own. Of course, for many it is a safer bet to shoot some pictures with little overhead and pick a small paycheck than going for larger jobs but having to do and purchase everything on their own.  I do not know where you live, but if you want to get a better idea, then reach out to photographers in your area and well, ask them. I am sure more than a few will not mind giving some advise if you ask politely and respectfully.

The term “expensive” is relative. I’ve been told I’m too expensive when I was charging $750 for a wedding, $1,800 and $4,500. It all comes down to what you place your value in. I’ve had potential wedding clients who were both six-figure earners and came from wealthy families that scoffed at my $2,800 starting price. While I’ve also had couples who work low-paying jobs and I know struggled to come up with a deposit and took sides jobs and cut back to pay the rest of their $5,600 wedding photography collection. So while I think it’s crazy someone would pay $500 for a pair of jeans, $2,000 on a set of kitchen knives, $600 for a hair appointment, or $5,000 on a television, that is what those people put value on. Now to answer in a more straightforward way, a lot of the commenters already touched on the pricing of wedding photography: Cost of Doing BusinessBillable hours (25 weddings per year at an average of 48 hours per wedding)Hard costs (albums, prints, cards, etc.)If you find someone who is charging a fairly low wage, more often or not it’s a side job. They have other income to cover their living expenses. For most full-time wedding photographers, we’re in charge of our own income, taxes, insurance and retirement.

First, it totally depends on the quality of your photographer, the contents of your Photography Collection, and also the City where your wedding takes place. On the latter point, it goes without saying that a wedding photographer in New York City or LA would be more expensive than in some small town on the outskirts of, say, Atlanta. Sure, you can look at widely available statistics, such as the average wedding cost of about $25k-$30k in the U.S. Then you can extrapolate how much of that wedding budget goes to photography. Depending on the source, many folks recommend anywhere between 6–15%. Where in that range your allocation falls depends on how important photos are to you. Note that many of these sources also lump video services into the photography budget. Also, some of the total wedding budget figures do not include additional photography services (different from your wedding weekend), such as boudoir, engagement, honeymoon, additional albums, travel, second or third photographer, drone/aerial photos, etc. Percentage calculations are a touch misleading for more expensive weddings, where just the floral design might cost $200,000. Or if you have a wedding with, say, 800 guests who would drive up the catering costs. There are photographers who will capture your wedding for $500 and some who will charge you $60,000+. Ultimately, you get a bit of what you pay for as long as you do some research, interview your potential photographers, and invest confidently in their services (do NOT fall in love with a single image, a stylized portfolio, model shoot, etc. since it is not a reflection of what you should expect for your own wedding). Be forthcoming in the information you provide to your photographers and they will be more inclined to want to work with you and provide additional value in your collection. A wedding photography collection is a fancy term for the photography package you commission. At a minimum, you need one principal photographer for your ceremony and a good portion of your reception. However, most brides will book a photographer to start sometime during the “getting-ready” coverage (i.e. prepping) and conclude their coverage at the very tail-end of their wedding (usually when the party is over). Clearly, the more hours you commission, the more you need to pay. The photographer will spend more time photographing your wedding, as well as editing your photos and other related post-wedding services. The quality of your photographer is a bit subjective. Her work needs to appeal to you first as opposed to editors of magazines or the judges of photo competitions. With that said, first start by examining their online reviews (Google, Yelp, WeddingWire, Facebook, website of the artist, etc.). Now, of course, demand for an artist will ultimately drive the price. So if an artist is popular (in-demand), you should expect to pay a premium. And look early (at least 6–12 months before your wedding date) if the photographer is popular. Hope that helps and good luck!

Wedding photography coverage cost can vary greatly. It’ll depend on a few things: Duration of coverage (hours? days?)Location (how far is it from where the photographer is based? If far, the client usually pays for the hotel stays and transportation costs)Quality of the photographerExpectations of the clients (does the client want a second shooter or a third shooter [applicable for weddings say, with over 500+ guests])When booking a wedding photographer, one should consider all of above factors. If price shopping, you can easily find people willing to do it for free or for $500 USD on Craigslist. The problem is that the quality will be likely very questionable. For anyone respectable and experienced, you should expect to pay at least $3,000–4,000 for a minimum of 8+ hours of coverage. Do keep in mind that albeit a few thousand dollars for a day’s worth of shooting seems like a lot, higher end photographers carry thousands, of not tens of thousands of dollars worth of equipment (and have backup equipment as well), and have invested a lot of time in training and learning. They also have a lot of experience, which means that they’ll be able to work in more difficult situations if they need to. The hours they spend post-processing is in addition very time-consuming—anywhere from 2–6x the hours spent shooting (if your wedding was 8 hours of coverage, a higher-end photographer might spend up to 40–50 hours culling and editing your photos). The best way to get a sense of this is to simply Google up local photographers, and see how their prices vary (and do take note of the comparisons in quality). Better photographers will have photos in all scenarios (getting-ready, portraits, outdoor/indoor ceremonies, reception, etc.). The weaker photographers usually don’t have many indoor-at-night photos because they don’t know how to light receptions. You can even use my website (in bio) as a reference. Do keep in mind that you get what you pay for. It’s the same with dining at a really nice restaurant: the chef not only has nicer tools, but they know how to cook better. ;) The only difference is that your photos are your memories captured made sharable.

A few (hopefully) helpful recommendations: KNOW your worth!! You are now working as a Professional. Not a “new wedding photographer.” This means you have strong technical and creative foundational skills, the gear, the portfolio of high quality images from being a second-shooter at dozens of other weddings for other photographer(s) so that you can comfortably discuss wedding shots and ideas with the couple like a pro should be able to fluently discuss. You also have the business end of things set up, the insurance, the liability, the LLC, the primary and backup bodies and lenses, the lighting, the contracts, the website, the post-processing tools and experience, the reliable transportation, the second shooter, consultation/pre-sales experience, the bookkeeper/keeping skills , marketing knowledge, the relationships, the passion, and more that you have had to develop, purchase, acquire and practice! So do not undervalue that for yourself—or for the many pro photographers who have walked this walk before you. Don’t forget you also have overhead, ongoing professional development costs, and unexpected expenses that arise. Yet…Rise up! Believe in yourself!!! Sometimes that will be all you can hold onto for a whole as you start out! But it is critical—do hold faith in yourself and your ability to always learn, create and grow!If you do not have the things listed in #1, please go back to #1 and get them. They are not really optional if you are a Professional. This is your client’s most important day in their life thus far and you do not want to implode your business and reputation, your savings, or your sanity if you can’t deliver for them. Some types of photography business are more forgiving. Weddings are sadly not. So don’t practice at the expense of the couple. There are no re-do’s. Be a solid second-shooter first until you feel quite familiar with it all. Besides you will have the confidence you gain on your side when it comes to charging what you need to make this sustainable.If you are good with #1 and #2, my best next advice is to decide your value. And the realities of the work. To do so, I personally estimate that for every hour at a wedding and reception shooting live, there are about 8–12 hours of work before and after the event for you. (E.g., consultation time, paperwork prep, billing, calls, scouting the location, coordinating with the other services like the baker, minister, etc., prepping gear, transportation time, time scheduling and briefing second shooter, packing/loading/unpacking at each location of wedding/reception/other shooting spots, and at home, time buffers for arriving early and staying late when stuff. Gets off schedule as many weddings do, post processing time, post-wedding proof prep, the meeting to show the bride her images afterward and make sales, follow-up time, ordering prints for bride, sending thank yous, bookkeeping, etc.Knowing your hours and your actual costs, labor time, etc should help you realistically (important) understand why someone charging $1000 to do a wedding will never ever have a sustainable business model. They are working for pennies or offering so many compromises that you are in a race to the bottom. There are many at the bottom competing for crumbs as it is.Now consider tiered pricing. You can have a $1000 option, but you are designing it to not really be a viable or great choice for most. You want to have the mid and upper tiers be your goal. (Remember the sales rule that when given three tiers of pricing, most never pic the bottom or top).Own your worth. Set your price fairly. You are a valuable service (assuming #1 above is all there), and you are seeking a win-win trade from someone needing your services. Then after your first few weddings, evaluate the feedback, adjust along the way, and increase your prices as you gain more experience. That said, if you set the pricing too low (and you are decent) you will get referrals from people who also have that same budget. So you want to be sure the word of mouth you want is from the clientele you want to draw today and I’m the future.I didn’t give you a number to charge as I don’t know anything about your local market or business goals. But I hope this helps guide you and best of luck!

The million dollar question! A quick Google search will turn up a billion photographers out there, all desperate for work and many of them will be happy to walk away with only a few hundred pounds. It is hard to answer your question precisely as the average salary salary of a wedding photographer will depend on so many variables including important factors such as your target demographic (i.e. what kind of couples and weddings you are hoping to work with) as well as the region where your market is based. Here in the UK, a London wedding photographer can earn anything from £100 per hour to £10,000 per day…..though the higher up the food chain you go, the bigger the reward and the less likely that those photographers will be found using a simple Google search. The uber high end wedding photographers can command really, really big money. There was a photographer in the US called Gary Fong who famously kept inflating his prices over and over again until he was famously charging $100,000 a day. Unsurprisingly he’s since retired from wedding photography! I heard that a very well known photographer in the States (who I won’t name) charges $30,000 a day, though he is world famous and works with the very best wedding planners on the planet. He’s also incredibly talented which helps a lot. So in summary, the world is your oyster. If you want to earn really big money, aim high and shoot for the stars because everybody has to start somewhere. Though if you are happy to get by on an average wage, then it is absolutely possible to do so and to be happy in the process. Wedding photography is a lovely way to earn a living. You get to hang out with people on the happiest of days, surrounded by love and you are the person who is blessed to document the day in pictures. Sounds like a win win to me! Go for it, I say.

I am offering common sense tips here, I am not a wedding photographer specialist. Pricing depends on several variables such as location and region and the time requested, does it include video, do you need rehearsal dinner and wedding day and what you order in your package. Is this a small wedding or large one. Some photographers will post your photos on a website to pick your photos and some will prepare photo books and other prints or digital media, so make sure you know what your price includes. The photographers experience will factor here too, some are non-negotiable as their reputation speak for itself. Some photographers are contractors so they may have an agency to help locate someone and have extra fees build in. You could pay from $2,000-$ 10000 and more. Most people will shop around according to their budget and others spare no expense when it comes to photographers. It’s the most important part of the wedding plans to remember. Remember they should carry insurance and have the proper equipment to meet your needs. You can expect to pay ~ $ 4- 6,000 for a decent day. ***I’m not a wedding photographer, so I quote this based on other people I know. Independent local photographers can offer the good prices and services since they tend to be low key advertisers. Look at their portfolio and pricing options for what you want.

How much does a wedding photographer cost? Wedding photographer prices can vary depending on many factors including your wedding’s location (photographers in big cities tend to cost more than in other areas), the type of services and packages you’re looking for, and your chosen photographer’s experience and level of expertise. In general, wedding photographer prices in the IN. tend to range between 8000 and 20,000, with the average wedding photographer cost hovering around 10000. Your wedding photographer will likely comprise about 12 percent of your overall wedding budget. What's covered in a wedding photographer’s prices? When researching wedding photographers, be sure to read the information about their pricing and packages carefully—these tend to differ widely from photographer to photographer and can greatly affect wedding photography pricing. A few items and services to look for include: Time: Wedding photographer prices typically include between six hours and an unlimited amount of coverage. The more time you’d like your photographer to cover your event, the more you’ll have to pay. Additional hours will cost extra.Travel: Does your photographer have to travel a long distance to your event? You may have to pay a per-mile charge if he or she is driving to your wedding, or you might have to pay for airfare and accommodations for a destination wedding.Second Shooters/Staffing: Will your photographer have a second shooter or assistants present? If so, expect to shell out more.Editing: A large part of your photographer’s time will be spent editing and retouching your wedding photos to make sure they look absolutely amazing.Images: Your wedding photographer’s cost should include the actual images. Digital files can be provided to you in a variety of ways including in an online gallery and/or via a USB drive.Print release: Many wedding photography packages include a “print release,” which means that you can use the photos for your own personal use. However, be aware that you will likely not have a full “copyright release,” so you don’t own the photos and can’t sell them, and that your photographer can use your photos for marketing purposes.Prints: Some photographers include photo prints (or a print credit—money you can put toward purchasing prints) in their wedding photography rates. While you don’t have to purchase your prints through your photographer, they’ll likely come out better if you do.Albums: Your photographer may offer a wedding album as part of his or her package. You can choose whether you’d like to design and purchase your album through your photographer or do it through another service.Additional shoots: Some photographers include an engagement shoot in their package (62 percent of couples do a pre-wedding engagement shoot). Other shoots that will likely cost extra include bridal portraits, trash the dress sessions, or coverage of your rehearsal dinner.There are other, less obvious parts of a wedding photographer’s business that may be included in their package pricing, which include equipment, employees, business expenses, marketing, liability insurance, and more. Do I need to tip my wedding photographer? While tips aren’t included in a photographer’s package, they are certainly something you should factor into your wedding photography budget. If your photographer owns his or her business, you don’t need to tip, but if he or she works for a larger company, a 500 to 1000 tip is a nice gesture. You should also write an online review for your photographer as an added thank-you. When should you hire a wedding photographer? Wedding photographers are usually among the first vendors couples book after they secure their venue. We recommend starting the search for your photographer about 11 months before your big day. What are the different wedding photography styles? As you start researching wedding photographers by checking out their work and reading their online reviews, be sure to pinpoint the wedding photography style you like best. There are a few wedding photography styles to choose from, including: Photojournalism: This wedding photography style is all about telling a story. The photographer will capture candid, emotional moments as opposed to posed portraits.Traditional: A more formal, classic photography style, traditional wedding photography includes lots of posed shots.Fine Art: This style is all about dramatic compositions and stylized images. It’s a more modern approach that creates frame-worthy images.Fashion: If you want images that focus on your attire and look like they belong in a magazine, this is the wedding photography style for you. Think creative backdrops and unique poses.Vintage: This photography style uses filters and other techniques to give your wedding photos an old-school feel.Should I get a second shooter for my wedding? When it comes to the great “one versus two wedding photographers” debate, the “right” answer tends to vary from photographer to photographer, and often depends on the size of your wedding. If you’re having a very intimate and small wedding, having just one photographer present may suffice. However, if you’re hosting a larger wedding with lots of guests, you will likely need a main photographer as well as a second photographer, and perhaps assistants to help with lighting and coordination. 35 percent of wedding photographers include a second shooter in their starting rates, but for many, it's a separate charge. Having a second shooter can be beneficial in capturing different perspectives and angles throughout the day—and can make your wedding-day timeline run even more smoothly. With two photographers on hand, both your and your future spouse’s getting-ready processes can be photographed at the same time. It’s best to discuss your specific wedding and needs with your photographer to determine the best staffing situation. Are albums included in a wedding photographer's prices? Many photographers do include an album in their wedding photography rates. However, some photographers offer it as a separate line item, which can add several hundred dollars to your total. There are indeed other services that allow you to create your own wedding photo album, but it can sometimes be more seamless to go through your own photographer. Do I have to cover my wedding photographer's travel costs? If your wedding photographer is based near your wedding location, you likely won’t have to pay any additional travel costs. However, if your photographer will be traveling a significant distance (often over 60 miles), you will likely incur additional travel costs, up to $2 per mile or more. If your photographer is flying to your wedding destination, you will probably have to pay for his/her airfare and accommodations, as well as an additional travel fee. Again, these wedding photographer prices vary from pro to pro, so be sure to ask your chosen photographer for pricing details before booking. Do I have to pay for my wedding photographer's meals? For your wedding vendors who will be present during your actual wedding (your photographer, videographer, DJ, wedding planner, etc.) you will need to provide hot meals. Yes, this is indeed an added expense that you might not have expected to incur, but it’s an important one—vendors who are well-fed and happy will better be able to bring their A-game for your big day! Your wedding caterer is likely accustomed to providing these vendor meals, so be sure to discuss this with them. Tahnku

Photographer here who has done a few weddings. I can honestly say that I've never had my expenses covered. The amount of time it takes to edit wedding photos can go into the hundreds of hours if you're anal like me, colour balancing, cropping, retouching and so on… then there's requests for certain photos at certain sizes (where crops don't work), customer service, the actual shooting (which literally takes anywhere from 1% to 30% of the job's actual time and so on. If I did the math, them I would want $2000 for shooting the event plus post-processing which would quickly amount to $6000 or more total. Don't forget you're paying for the experience and artistic eye of the photographer. Good gear is important too, which only increases the cost when a single lens can cost over $2000. You can hire your “cwac” (cousin with a camera) and they'll probably do a good job, but a good wedding photographer has poses, experience and technical knowledge to get the most out of an occasion. For that once in a lifetime event trust a professional. Trust me.

What amount does a wedding picture taker cost? Wedding picture taker costs can fluctuate contingent upon numerous elements including your wedding's area (photographic artists in enormous urban communities will in general cost more than in different zones), the sort of administrations and bundles you're searching for, and your picked photographic artist's understanding and level of skill. As a rule, wedding picture taker costs in the U.S. will in general range somewhere in the range of $1,150 and $3,000, with the normal wedding picture taker cost drifting around $2,000. What's canvassed in a wedding picture taker's costs? A couple of things and administrations to search for include: Time: Wedding picture taker costs commonly incorporate between six hours and a boundless measure of inclusion. The additional time you'd like your picture taker to cover your occasion, the more you'll need to pay. Extra hours will cost extra. You may need to pay a for each mile charge in the event that the individual in question is heading to your wedding, or you may need to pay for airfare and facilities for a goal wedding. Second Shooters/Staffing: Will your picture taker have a subsequent shooter or colleagues present? Provided that this is true, hope to dish out additional. Altering: An enormous piece of your picture taker's time will be spent altering and correcting your wedding photographs to ensure they look completely stunning. Pictures: Your wedding photographic artist's expense ought to incorporate the real pictures. Computerized records can be given to you in an assortment of ways remembering for an online exhibition or potentially by means of a USB drive. Print discharge: Many wedding photography bundles incorporate a "print discharge," which implies that you can utilize the photographs for your very own utilization. In any case, know that you will probably not have a full "copyright discharge," so you don't claim the photographs and can't sell them, and that your picture taker can utilize your photographs for promoting purposes. Prints: Some picture takers incorporate photograph prints (or a print credit—cash you can put toward buying prints) in their wedding photography rates. While you don't need to buy your prints through your picture taker, they'll likely come out better on the off chance that you do. Collections: Your picture taker may offer a wedding collection as a major aspect of their bundle. You can pick whether you'd prefer to structure and buy your collection through your picture taker or do it through another assistance. Extra shoots: Some picture takers incorporate a commitment shoot in their bundle (62 percent of couples do a pre-wedding commitment shoot). Different shoots that will probably cost extra incorporate wedding representations, junk the dress meetings, or inclusion of your practice supper. There are other, more subtle pieces of a wedding picture taker's business that might be remembered for their bundle estimating, which incorporate hardware, representatives, operational expense, promoting, obligation protection, and the sky is the limit from there.

It depends on how long your wedding is: These prices are for unlimited images, and I personally always shot with 2 cameras in case there was a malfunction in one. Ceremony only 1 hour: around $250 Ceremony and Formals 2 hour: $400 Reception: 4 hours $800 Getting ready, Ceremony, formals, Reception $1400 Package deal: $1200–4,000 depending on how famous your photographer is. P.S. This does not include the images. Most people will buy the images to own them, and do their own printing and online album. A newbie may charge $100. But, you must pay more for an experienced photographer who actually knows what to do to get the great shots. Don’t forget, that newbies may lose every shot due to some unforseen problem. PLEASE, do not hire your non professional friend to do your wedding, and then when he/she makes a mistake, become a jerk, and sue your friend who is doing you a wonderful favor!!! UNFORTUNATELY, THAT HAPPENS ALL THE TIME, SO WISE UP friend, and don’t lose your life’s savings trying to help a friend just because they are begging you to do it. IF you do, then make sure that you have a signed contract stating that you are NOT responsible for lost, damaged, improperly taken shots, even if you lose everything!

This is a tough question because it’s a value question, right? What do you, the couple getting married, value? I think you should budget between 15% to 20% of your total wedding budget on photography, but if you don’t care about photography you might laugh and say that is way to much. In most major markets you can find a photographer who will show up and take photographs in a style close to what you want for $3500. There isn’t a direct correlation between how much you spend and the quality of photos you get from your wedding photographer. But the photographer who makes $3500 a wedding has to photograph a lot of weddings to live in a major market, and has a lot less time to spend working on your images, emailing with you about your wedding timeline, or scouting your venue with you to find out what you like and don't like. Plus, the more time you spend with your photographer the more comfortable you are the better the images are and a photographer servicing a lot of clients doesn't have the time. Photographers also burn out very quickly over working themselves. When you are asking what is a reasonable price for a wedding photographer you first need to ask yourself what do I expect from my wedding photographer? Yes, a really amazing photographer is going to cost more. But more importantly a photographer who is going to have the time to connect with you, answer your questions quickly, and take care with your wedding photos is going to cost more as well. So, if you are still reading this I’d say plan to spend a minimum of $4500 if you want a good photographer, and don’t be surprised that amazing photos and great customer service will cost between $5500 and $7500. I also don’t think it would be unreasonable to spend more for wedding photography when your budget for the wedding get upwards of $65000, but at that point I’m guessing you might not be on Quora looking for what the answer to this question. Another good question I’d like to answer is why photography cost goes up to some degree as the overall cost of the wedding does.

Great Question, as there are many photographers out there that have NO Real Experience Photographing a Wedding which is a One Time Life Event. There’s no going back & doing reshoots. Meet with Photographers, look at Samples of their work of Weddings. Not just their Best Shots. Anyone can do that. When I started doing Weddings I always shot with an Experienced Wedding Photographer and as I learned I increased my Price & what I offered. Now I typically hire a close Friend that’s also a Professional Photographer to shoot Weddings with me as there’s no way on a good sized Wedding, or a Jewish or Greek Wedding One Photographer can be everywhere & Capture all the Special moments as some of those Weddings have Strict Restrictions on where a Photographer can be & do, such as a Greek Wedding there’s No Photos allowed during Prayer and you can be moving around during one either so with Two Photographers I can be assured that I can deliver to the couple all of those Special moments plus when shooting the Couple, Attendants, Family etc after the Ceremony one Photographer does the groupings, Posing / how & where to stand while the other Shoots the Photos while the other one assures everyone looks good as he looks on, and time is of the essence during this time so everyone can get to the Reception as Guest are awaiting the Happy Couple & Attendants so two photographers cuts the photo time in half also. So look at Samples of Weddings, ask how they work , arrival for Bride & Groom Dressing, Time they will be there and how do they work with finding out who everyone is that’s important as in Family Members etc that you’d want photographed, as I always have the Bride assign one of her Best Friends or a Sister etc.. , who knows everyone & who the Bride & Groom want photographed. I do this because it’s the Bride & Grooms Special Day & last thing they need is a Photographer to be constantly bugging them who & what they’d like photographed and there’s no way to know beforehand & this way I can be assured of capturing all Special people & Family they’d like photographed as there’s usually people from out of town that traveled there and working with someone that agreed to help the Bride leaves the Happy Couple able to just Enjoy their Special Day. Pricing will vary by photographers. Speak to several, get recommendations etc to find that One Photographer that you like him or her , their work and how you feel their work with you. You’ll get pretty much what you pay for with an Experienced Wedding Photographer as there’s no reshoots. I also offer “For Your Eyes Only” shoots for the Bride, Photos of the couple at a place or park of their choice. hope all this has helped.

Wedding photography is a very difficult and time consuming business. Anything to do with weddings is extremely subjective because there are usually a lot of “experts” who give negative advice (like mothers of the brides and ‘wedding planners’) and who have very little actual expertise. A wedding photographer must make a good deal of money because most people want their weddings on Saturdays and there is a limited number of those. Now you have a bunch of people with phone cameras who can be nervy enough to compare their snapshots to the work of a skilled professional and will do so on the spot just to try to embarrass the guy. I have been asked to do weddings and have always demurred. It requires a particular skill set that few photographers have. Somebody asked recently about wildlife photography and I said the main requirement was patience. Wedding photogs have to have way more of that. (The critters seldom bitch about your technique. They might try to eat you but they rarely care about the picture.) You’re dealing with a (More or less) once in a lifetime experience and people who often school themselves to be annoyingly self-centered on “Their Day.” Most wedding photographers have all of my respect and none of my envy.

Hopefully you are not just “jumping” into this new career without proper thought and experience. Prior to me shooting weddings I served as an apprentice at a large studio (lugging gear, doing set-ups, loading the cameras with film, posing the groups etc.). eventually I was allowed to shoot as a back-up to heck how good my images were compared to the prime photographer. Eventually I got good enough to go out on my own with the studio’s blessing. It was a process. In all I shot over 300 weddings and did quite well. I also had a home studio that brought in cash. What you charge depends on your experience, training, gear, knowledge and expenses. Remember one thing, if you screw up one time it will haunt you for life. You are capturing irreplaceable memories of a huge day in people’s lives so don’t ever take this job lightly. I was fortunate to never mess up ever and always gave more than was asked for. If you have a girl friend, take time to check out local studios to see what they are charging (pose as a potential client) or go online and check prices if they list them. This is a very competitive business with a bunch of hacks trying to undercut your price. I had a sliding scale based on how much effort went into the job. From simply delivering the DVDs of images from a simple “second marriage” two hour evening ceremony to full blown albums, mother’s books, proof books and framed prints I made sure to make it worth my while. Cheers!

This has been asked before. There is no fixed cost for a wedding event. There are so many factors to consider, from the reputation, skills, technical prowess, insurance, etc…there are so much to consider. Each couple has their own uniques wishes to be fullfiled and rightly so. Some are quite easy and routine for us. However, the most over riding factor I do consider is the Complexity of the wishes. My deals are pretty standard, it always for three days, pre, post and game day. With my routine, thats pretty much 3 full days of work but it is mostly the same price with others just for the wedding event day. I love weddings, I love photography so the extra time and effort and the extra thousands of photos are simply paradise for me to post process.Usually, my clients ends up with close to 4000 photos and several sets using my custom filters. Clients love the tons of photos they could share…it would take months for them to share it online…Which is a good bargain/ Again, deal with me tend to be middle to higher end range for most European Countries, I travel anywhere, and enjoy the experience as well. So with me I offer the lower pricing relative to others because for me its more of a paid hobby so I could buy new gadgets. It is just part business. My social media management works are enough. Plus being SMM helps as well so another bonus. So shop around and ask. There is no harm in asking…if the photographer is reluctant with entertaining legitimate client then its a red flag. Good luck with yoursearch.

First of all you want good pictures right? That requires experience, good equipment, and the psychological skills necessary to deal with all the fricking personalities colliding on a special occasion. In a wedding there are no do overs if something goes wrong. It’s similar to a war zone in that way. You have to get all the important shots in before anyone eats or spills wine all over their beautiful dresses and suits. So a good photographer is busy from the get go. The brides family, the groom’s family etc. Then there’s the work of editing, retouching, matting and framing. Plus the official wedding album and orders for pictures. Then there’s the costs of running your own business, and collecting when people refuse to pay off the balance or order things they can’t afford. It takes a special kind of person to do wedding photography. Sure it’s big money, but also big hassles, and a high level of risk involved. Plus most people have no idea what it entails and therefore think they can get away with getting the artsy college kid to take the pictures for cheap. All strategies have their plus and minus. Just remember you get what you pay for, and after 6 months you’ll probably never look at those pictures again lol.

I will hope you’re speaking about a professional that specializes in wedding photography and has a good reputation for shooting weddings. The range will likely start at $1,800 and go to $3,500. They can also be much higher depending on where they are and where your wedding will be (Distance away from your wedding location), what time of year (May through October - Wedding Season), What day of the week (Saturdays are usually the costliest) The wedding format Time needed to shoot all you wanted shot, whether a second or 3rd shooter is required. If your wedding is a several day affair, costs will be much higher. Go to bridal shows, visit the wedding websites that are in your area. Talk with them. You will be spending lots of time with them on your wedding day. There are many expenses that go into being a better wedding photographer that can include training, equipment, insurances and marketing to name a few. Hope that helps. Richard

Because you're paying for a skilled person for their livelihood. Shooting a wedding isn't 4 hours of work. It's a week or two of work with overhead expenses, and time invested in marketing themselves, selling, and they get to pay taxes too. If you think of their time as worth about $50 per hour, that's about $2000 for a wedding, and that is a solid baseline for a professional. In reality it's more than 40 hours of work. Costs will of course be higher for a good photographer or in an expensive area. If someone's services are in demand, they can charge more. They aren't going to charge a fee that they can't live on unless they're just a hobbyist photographer that is willing to do it for the experience. If you look at it as a full time job where you don't have work every week, you night understand the pricing better.

In my area, wedding photographers usually work for themselves - so salary isn't the right word.  In 1999 I worked for a company (since closed) that paid its photographers about $250 a wedding (it was a low end company).  Great experience tho, really. Oftentimes clients think that the $3,000 I charge for a wedding (average) is all going in my pocket.  Given that there are a limited number of days people get married (weekends) and a great deal of back end work, it's not a profession that leads to unlimited wealth in terms of money.   But if you truly love what you do, and I do, then it is a job that blurs the line between work and play.

The key to understanding average photographer salary is understanding of wedding market in your area. An excellent source for such information is the annual survey of American brides from The Knot the results of which are released during March of each year. Here are some findings that should help you be more knowledgeable about the state of the wedding market and how it is connected with photography costs (for USA):Wedding Photographers! How Well Do You Know the Wedding Market and Your Target Customers? Average wedding budget: $28,427 (excludes honeymoon).Most expensive place to be married: Manhattan, $76,678 average.Least expensive place to be married: Alaska, $15,504 average.Average spent on a wedding dress: $1,211.So it is quite logical considering $28,427 spent on the average wedding, the average photography expenditure is $2,379.

It doesn’t? If you have a wedding photographer for 10 hours at £1000 which is an average price then let’s break it down. 10 hours at the day = £100 ph 10 hours for backing up, editing and delivering so that’s now 20 hours of work = £50 ph The wedding photographer is running a business so he is paying out for things like web hosting, marketing, insurance and travel costs this can be anywhere from £100-£1000 a month. As a business they also need some profit to invest back in to the business for things like equipment. You will find a lot of wedding photographers actually working for nearly minimum wage when they are trained professionals and should be on more than a pizza delivery boy.

Depending on the requirements , and the photography crew and the number of events that needed to be covered it will vary. I got married on last May and the total cost was 65k excluding their hotel arrangements.I got married in Calicut,Kerala. This crew included 5 people and they covered the marriage for 3 days. The package costs included candid photography, videography,album editing ,video editing and the equipements.The total charge will increase if the number of sheets in your wedding album increases. This was actually a sweet deal considering the number of days and the events that had to cover. But normally for weddings in Kerala if you go by the above package it will take 1 to 2 lakhs for one day wedding. This will also include outdoor shooting and use of equipements like drone for video shooting .Yes you heard it right. Drones. (Will upload a pic as soon as I get it.)

There are many things to consider: Where are you? Where are the photos to be taken? How many? Wedding Album? Digital? Film? Travel Expenses (For Photographer) / During the week? / Weekend? / Wedding and Reception? / Family? / Wedding Party? / Guests? / This is not an easy thing to answer! Check local sources for prices and “What is offered in services for that price.” Bear in mind…. “Go cheap…. you can be disappointed!” If this is your Once in a lifetime moment! Think hard. If you want Snapshots… have family and friends take photos for you. You can even buy inexpensive “Disposable cameras!” But don’t regret what you do! Draw up a contract with photographer! Do not leave out Unanswered Questions!… You can get burned! or will be very disappointed. MaxStorm 20/20 Photography.

It is not easy to say that a wedding photographer costs. it varies from place to place, and you may consider it also varies from different photographer and the requirements and it depends upon how long your wedding is. Now-a-days, there are many wedding photographers available. Some of are locals and have average quality photography and they demand low money for their services. and the big and professionals photographers provide their services and they charges more costs. If you need two or more photographers or more time to capture or video recordings it costs more money. The best wedding professional photography service named Rain Star photography in Singapore. We provide both ROM photography and wedding Actual day photography. We at Rain star photography charge wedding Photographer costs for ROM photography S$200 for one hour, S$300 for two hours including photos montage clip and S$500 for 4 hours , S$900 for ten hours for wedding actual day photography.

Budget is a huge part of every wedding. Tel Aviv Wedding Photographer is one aspect of your big day we’d advise you not to scrimp on. We’re all for DIY weddings and doing as much of it all you can yourself, but we think your photography is something that’s worth investing in. You’ll be looking back at these photos for years to come, so you want them to be the best they possibly can be to remind you of what a special day your wedding was. The average cost for a wedding photographer is $2,814.The typical wedding photography package usually offers extent for 8 hours. Adding more or less time will increase or decrease that price. Engagement sessions can sometimes be included or run extra. I’ve seen experienced photographers charge anywhere between $1,000-$3,000 for a wedding album, and will sometimes offer a further discount depending on the amount of wedding coverage you buy.

In a nutshell? It's a whole lot of work, requires expensive equipment, and exceptional interpersonal skills. The environment often cannot be controlled, so the photographer has to very good at judging the good shot from an excellent one in a matter of seconds. The photographer bears the burden of selecting the pictures for you, and should deliver an excellent visual story. It is a lot of work. Demanding work at that. You are paying someone who is a technician, an artist, an engineer, and a writer. And on top of it all, that poor soul has to put up with a drunk wedding party. Pay up!

Depending on where you live, plan to spend $1,500 for a small package from a photographer that you admire for their style and photo gallery examples… to upwards of $50,000+ if you want a top photographer who shoots society weddings… a lot of photographers do not prefer to shoot weddings as the moments happen quickly and the photographer has to deal with action, lighting changes, and then spend days editing the photos. They have to create a memory that is pleasing for the wedding couple and family. Besides cost, the most important goal should be finding a photographer that you like based on his/her style… you might be surprised at the affordability of the one or two you like the most. Good luck!

Wedding photographer cost depends upon their service. A strong wedding photographer is expected to help make your day fitter. Aside from a professional wedding planner, the photographer is the only salesman who can spend the entire day with you. A good photographer on wedding will make things simpler for you. When hiring your wedding photographer, the most important thing to keep in mind is that the photos will be part of your family's history forever-so please choose with your heart! I hired a wedding photographer from Eric Webb Photography who clicked very nice photos in an affordable price.

I am not sure how much a photographer cost. Let me offer you some advice about a photographer. Start early and interview them so the photographer can get to know your personality and exactly what you want. When the wedding is over and it will go by very quickly all you will have will be your pictures. This in my opinion is where you need to spend the most money because they will capture everything you want so you will have great memories.

That depends on how much work they have to do, how many images they’re delivering, and how good they are. I’m sure you can find someone with a camera who will do it for a free dinner and gas money. On the other end of the scale, Annie Leibovitz is reported to charge $100,000 - $250,000 a day. National average for wedding photographers in the US is around $3000, but typical rates can be as low as $1000 and as high as $8000. You generally get what you pay for.

You’ll be surprised, most of your more experienced photographers do charge quite a bit ($1500 to $3000) depending on where you live but you can find good photographers who don’t charge as much by using search engines. You’ll be able to find professionals who are willing to work with you on what you will require. Most photographers will have websites where you can see their photos and many will also have reviews that your can read. The photographers that charge the most are not necessarily the best they just know how to manipulate social media. Let your own taste in photography guide you. If it looks good go with it. Be your own critic. And check out reviews.

I will tell the average amount to be spent on a wedding photographer. But before that i would like to tell that why photographer is so important in wedding. Wedding is one of the most important days of your life and you need a good photographer who can document it all and not miss the small detail. Purpose of the wedding photographs is to say a story, capture the beginnings of new life and moments of the day so every time you look at your photos, they will become alive in front of your eyes. ❤️ So before investing money on photographer you should trust on photographer. I got married 6 months back. And I spent around 35k which includes a album which have more than 200 pictures and video coverage of all important functions like mehandi , haldi, ladies sangeet , baraat reception and vidai etc. and I was very happy with the work of photographer. sharing some pictures from my marriage hope you will like it 😄      🤩 Thank you for reading.

Well a broad general question will grant you a broad general answer. Without knowing anything about your wedding such as how long will the photographer work (big key piece of info) I would say $300 for 1 camera person (entry level with own gear) to 3000 (1 or 2 photographers for 8 hours) $15,000 for 3–5 professional photographers and possible a director that will also shoot video and edit footage along with photos.

About 10 to 20 percent of what you will be spending on the entire wedding. Twenty years down the line no one will remember the expensive décor or the food, but you can relive the wedding by looking at the photo album and video filming. That is about the only thing left of the wedding that you can share with your children and grandchildren. So you decide which is the most important, the expensive wedding cake, the expensive dress and outfits, the number of people invited, the five course meal and the drinks provided, or the lasting memories of the photo album. I rest my case.

This is a hard question to answer. Prices are highly dependent on your region, on what you’re looking for in terms of season and time… and talent. In my area, (NYc/ northern NJ) great photographers, for full packages, run 4000.0 and up. Look at entire portfolios. Interview. If you’re in my area, please feel free to contact me for refs.

The better question is how much do you value photographs of your wedding? Based on that how much can you and your new wife afford? Set a budget And stick to it, interview a few photographers. If you can’t find one you can afford then you’re not looking hard enough. Wedding photographs can be a treasure to remind you of a special moment in your life. That said, there is nothing more important to your new life together than financial security and managing your finances.

Wedding photographers generally offer packages based on the number of hours, if they need a 2nd or 3rd shooter, and deliverables. In my experience, $500.00/hour is a starting point. That said, you can easily spend $12,500.00 - $25,000.00 depending on how important having great photography is to you, who the photographer is, and if the photographer incurs expenses like travel, hotel, food, etc.,

Have you ever assisted a real professional at a wedding? If you have and you have been paid as an assistant then charge 2/3rds of what the other photographer charges. If however you have not or if you only did it a few times then perhaps it is not appropriate for you to charge as your skill level might not be high enough.

About as much as the length of that piece of string over there!! A photographer should charge whatever they think is the appropriate price for whatever assignment they are doing. How they work that charge out depends on a number of things all of which will differ between photographers and assignments.

I would budget as much as reasonably possible on wedding photography. After all, the photographer is capturing your most magical moments - so you can remember your big day for a lifetime. On average couples spend $2,500 and up on photography. Don’t have that much? Not sure what you can spend and how much you need? Okay, at first, this question looked terrible because, as a wedding photographer, during the wedding shooting, money matters usually do not interfere. We only ask for amounts that we do for the quality of work that we try and take. There is a lot of hard work and thoughtfulness. However, I would like to add here that if there is a difference in cost of two photographers, then there is definitely a difference between the quality of production of the work.

It all depends on the requirement of a particular person. If its a destination wedding, then it would cost accordingly which can be around 1 to 2 K. If its a usual wedding but you need it to be shot as per different concepts then it will cost accordingly. In addition, type of cameras, crew members, and everything gets included. It can cost around 1 lakh and above. It’s always better to get a free quote from the wedding photographer.

There are many explanations for why photographers — good ones, especially — charge what they charge. The first one that comes to mind is that they charge enough to stay in business, to sustain their business, and dare to grow. For these people, photography is not just a business, but a passion. It’s not a hobby, even if it once was. They don't have a day job to finance their picture taking. This is it, baby.

Ever covered a wedding? I’ve done it twice, and it was like covering a war both times. And no one was actually fighting — it wasn’t one of those weddings either time. It’s hard, it’s stressful, you have to manage a huge amount of randomness, and you have to deliver. That would be my guess.

How much you spend depends on your budget. There are a lot of factors that go into figuring out the right price to pay. Some of the main factors are how many hours you want their services for, what you want included in your photo package and the location of your wedding relative to where the photographer is based.

Wedding photography charges range from thousands to lakhs depending on whom you want to cover the event, the number of days , number of album sheets and the equipment you need. to get a fair idea on kerala wedding photography and videography packages, you can check these sites. I would suggest you to shortlist a few good companies and send them emails with detailed event and location details. If you already have a budget, please share that too. This will make the whole process much easier.

Anything from a few quid for some amateur with a dslr who thinks they are pro through to thousands for a top of the line professional. figure out what YOUR budget is for photography and then shop around. Remembering the old adage of “you get what you pay for”.
Cost depends on your location and what you want in a wedding package. I am based in Tucson, AZ and offer packages from $1200–2500. You can expect that to double in places like Southern California.

There are 2 things you must pay out money on for your wedding ceremony, it should be your location and your photography. Camera equipment is costly and you must ensure your photographer is wholly insured by a reputable insurance company to ensure you are protected.

It depends on their level of experience. You will pay thousands for a top notch wedding photographer but you can hire one that has less experience and still does a great job for a fraction of the cost.

Deciding on the wedding photography budget can be tricky and there are no set rules. But surely if couple work smartly, the can get good wedding photographer within their budget. I got a quote for for $800 (Canadian currency) for four hours of time, plus tax. It will be a short civil wedding ceremony and a reception. The package will include photos on a USB stick. I’ll have to get them developed for an additional fee. Less time needed = a cheaper photographer.

Hi, if you have earned a brand name for yourself and your work is flawless and delivery on time then you can make an easy 5–6Lakhs per event depending on the size of the event. Maybe less may be more plus taking care of your team’s salary.

What? In this day and age when everyone is a photographer with a camera… nothing. I put in an Ad. All depends, but on an average, it can be anywhere from $2000 to $6000. Of course, if you’d like details, please contact me or visit my website. :)

Well the package cost will depend upon the type of photography required like traditional or candid, no. of years of experience of the photographer, skill set of the photographer, type of equipment used like crane,drone/cam copter etc. Taking into cognizance all the above criterion it may vary from Rs.10k to Rs.2 lacs a day in a tier 1 city for a good photography team.

Well, you don’t marry every year :) So, of course it’s not the cheapest service overall. But I like MOOD Photo & Video studio. I think their prices are pretty affordable. And of course high quality of work. That’s the most important thing!
In real terms, nothing at all, because the memories you get to keep from a skilled wedding photographer are priceless … worth far more than the financial cost of having the job done properly.
Roughly 10 percent of the total budget of the wedding is a standard if you are looking for a good coverage of the wedding.
The average cost for a wedding photographer is 35K The typical wedding photography package usually offers an extent for 8 hours.
Generally,7%-8% of your complete wedding budget should be a good ball park figure for amount to be spent on your wedding photographer.
About $5000–$10,000 for a fairly good one. Anything less and all bets are off on whether you get your money’s worth from your photos.

No... TWF does cinematography... and they charge double digit in lakhs. Exact quotes will have to check with them depending on requirements. But that is usually how much a middle class will spend on the entire wedding . So no, it's not affordable for a middle class family/couple.
